captions.text:
Good Morning John, it’s Friday...for the
last couple weeks, I’ve been thinking a

lot about boundaries. The boundary between
public and private. The borders between nations.

The thresholds of our lives. And the faultlines
of ideology. Interviewing President Obama

was something I could never regret, but being
thrown into the public eye has resulted in

some people saying nasty things about me,
which I’m actually not that used to.

So I’ve been trying to look at it all from
outside of my own experience. My graduate

degree is in environmental science, so I often
see my experiences through the lens of ecology.

Boundaries are exceptional places ecologically.
The area where two biomes blend is called

an ecotone and they tend to be more diverse
and biologically productive than either biome

alone. Many species specialize in survival
on that edge where access to both biomes increases
the available resources
The edge, in other words, is a fantastic place.

But it’s also a violent place. Predators
have access to more prey, and prey have to

watch for more predators. That tension is,
in nature, what drives increases in productivity
and diversity.

The edge between the land and the sea has
always been and remains a source of great

biological productivity, but it has also given
rise to great cultural and economic productivity.

The edge effect, it seems, exists outside
of ecology as well. There are personal edges,

whether it’s the finite moment a person
becomes a parent. Or a more drawn out transition,

like that of child to adult. Difficult times,
sure, but full of deeply valuable personal
growth.

Just as ecological boundaries are massively
productive, tumultuous, and wonderful, so

are boundaries between cultures. And in the
last week I’ve tried to see the political

debate in this country that way. I’ve tried
to imagine that the boundary between ideologies

is a productive yet tumultuous place, and
occasionally it is.

But the benefits from the boundary come not
from a harsh, edge. Where the ocean meets

a wall, the ecosystem does not become more
productive. The most productive ectones are

those stretched out over miles. The ocean
eating the land, the land eating the ocean

in a never-ending burbling that gives rise
to beautiful but impenetrable wetlands.

Instead of reaping the benefits of a gradient
between ideologies, I see people intentionally

poisoning it in order to protect their perceived
righteousness.

Eventually, you have what ecologists call
a monoculture...one plant as far as the eye

can see. A desert of diversity that may be
productive, but is extremely unstable. Any
outside influence can crash the entire system.

I do not want to live in a world of ideological
monocultures and I do not think that I do.

But pretending like we do is in the best interests
of a few people who happen to have a lot of
power.

So I do not propose dismantling the boundary...I
propose celebrating it. Ideological diversity

is not a sign of a divided nation, it’s
a sign of a thoughtful nation. And I’ve

found the best way to really believe this
is just to simply stop listening to the people

telling us to hate each other. As wrong as
you might think others are, you are never

always going to be right. Everyone will be
stronger if viewpoints are allowed to mix

into a diversity of ideas, and strategies.
The ecological success of the edge comes from

this mixing, and I think it’s an important
part of the success of democracy as well.

Yes, one side is going to feel safer to you,
it’s going to make more sense to you, but

to reach our full potential, we need the merge
that divide into a biome all its own, more

fertile, more diverse, and more productive
than we could ever be alone.
John, I’ll see you on Tuesday

comments.text:
I'm watching this video a few months after the fact. After browsing around 
through comments on here and in several ridiculously cruel articles, I am 
please to see that far more people defend Hank than attack him. Perhaps 
those who attacked him in the media had a larger audience, but those who 
defend him have done so intelligently and compassionately. I'm in the 
process of catching up on my Vlogbrothers videos, but I hope that by now 
Hank knows that the number and quality of those who love/respect him far 
surpass those who would tear him down.﻿
comments.author: Robyn Giles

comments.text: Hank... That was beautiful...﻿
comments.author: Truls Erik “Arise Comrades” Rypern

comments.text:
Hank Green, this reminds me of Donna Harraway's writings on Contact Zones. 
Have your read it?﻿
comments.author: Emily smith anciaux

comments.text:
People are scared of what they don't understand. I read some of the 
comments posted at the time. They were all of people (I assume adults, 
though I could be wrong) who assumed the YouTubers were pot-smoking, stupid 
clowns who didn't really understand the world around them. Insulting their 
intelligence aside, they also criticized Obama and how he was more willing 
to talk with "nobodies" (i.e. the YouTubers), rather than talk with global 
powerhouse leaders. 

The thing that irritates me, to the point that I actually laugh, is how 
they are so quick to apply labels in their little boxes of words they've 
come to know and love to any new "threat" or "idea". If they already didn't 
like Obama, then this surely shows that he is not worthy of Presidency, 
correct? I mean, it's asinine to think of a President actually *talking* 
with the people he's leading. That's ludicrous, they imply. 

My point is the same point Hank eloquently said in the video. I may 
paraphrase or severely truncate, but still: People love their borders. The 
fact that borders exist means that diversity on either side of it exists. 
Breaking the border and unleashing the bountiful diversity that exists in 
the zone where two biomes meet is more of a detriment than a positive one. 
Sure, more diversity exists, more growth arises, and more mixing occurs, 
but it's also very arduous to keep standing in such an awful area.

Maybe we need to rethink what Borders are meant to be. And maybe we need to 
realize that they aren't walls made of steel, meant to deter any outside 
influence. 
Doors exist for a reason. 
Maybe it'd be nice for us to open the door to new ideas every now and then 
to allow something beautiful to grow.﻿

comments.text:
This is a super interesting viewpoint... the parallels between Ecology and 
Economy are certainly not lost on me. I AIM towards his acceptance of 
political diversity and blurred boundary lines, but as he mentioned in the 
video, choosing a "side" is often the more comfortable thing to do. Partly 
because that's simply the way our political world is set-up... it's set-up 
to be a "we vs them" atmosphere and our politicians, our media, and 
ultimately, our public makes that atmosphere, makes that gap and those 
boundaries, stronger.  ﻿

comments.text:
I want to thank you for this video, Hank. There's a huge tendency among 
young liberal Americans right now to wholesale hate Republicans, and I have 
to admit it's attractive to construct an enemy out of an entire system of 
people and ideologies when some of them are doing things we disagree with 
some of the time. It's nice to hear someone whose views seem to relatively 
match my own encouraging intersection rather than division.﻿
comments.author: the_hawk12

comments.text:
Looking at the United States from the outside it's interesting to see how 
political boundaries have such an extreme affect on government. From my own 
personal observations, I think with a two party system the conflict (me 
verses you) is sort of built-in. I think political conflict can be 
productive because it inspires collective engagement from the public, but 
it also results in a lot of anger because of disagreement rather than 
debate. In Canadian politics (at least where I am on the west coast) we 
have conflict, but not many voters get aggressive about their political 
views. However, we also lack engagement.



    ﻿

comments.author: foreverwantingpie

comments.text:
I've been thinking about this kind of stuff since I was a kid. Celebrate 
diversity!...diversity of culture, race, religion, sexual orientation & 
etc. It makes life interesting. As long as we continue to "protect our own" 
at the expense of hurting others and stomping on their rights, our growth 
as human beings is going to be stunted and malformed. For example, 
respectfully expressing your point of view is cool. It's awesome to see how 
another person thinks from their perspective. But, you have to have an open 
mind and agree to disagree sometimes. But, beating others over the head 
with your views/beliefs is definitely NOT COOL!!! Everyone has a right to 
their POV (as long as they're not hurting anyone else), whether you like it 
or not.  Get used to it.  :)﻿
comments.author: Tina Davis

comments.text:

comments.author: gresha maskey

comments.text:
Hank...

I comment infrequently on your videos, because at the end of the day, they 
speak for themselves very well. However, I wanted to just lend my voice to 
the tumult, the veritable host of people who will be telling you "Hank, 
there comes a time in every human beings life, no matter how virtuous or 
endearing they may be, when they have to turn to someone and say, hey... 
Buddy... Screw you. I am doing my best, give me a damn break!" There is no 
shame in that, and I highly advise you to take that stance when people give 
you a hard time. You do more for this planet than pretty much ALL the 
people who have commented negatively toward you, and more for the human 
race as well. 

When you hear people bad mouth you, just look at the vast expanse that is 
Nerdfighteria, and remember that although the realm is made of the many, it 
started with yourself and your brother. Heck, I don't always agree with 
what you say, but none the less I recognise that you are a man of heart, of 
mind, and with music like you make, there is no doubt you have soul. You 
are doing just fine, keep it up, and don't let the bastards weigh you down. 

Listen to some Devin Townsend, and remember dude... You are loved. ﻿
comments.author: Peter Edwards

comments.text: Thank you for this, I found it very uplifting.﻿
comments.author: Leonard “Little Mr. Doomsday” Little

comments.text:
Wow. You know, Hank, I never really quite thought of politics that way. 
Previously, I thought that if everyone just got along and proceeded with 
one political ideology, it could work. I figured, if everyone were 
conservative or liberal or even communist, a government could work smoothly 
and effectively, and it could. However, if we have all of these different 
ideas, these different cultures and thought processes, we can mix and match 
the best of each idea, culture, and group of people to create a sort hybrid 
humanity. The way I like to think of it is with colors. Say America is 
blue, Kenya is green, China is brown, Germany is orange, Somalia is yellow, 
and so on and so on, and then we mix all of these colors. What do we get? 
Black. And everyone looks good in black. I know this analogy isn't 
complete, but hey, maybe someone with other ideas can help me make it 
better.﻿
comments.author: Dominic Phillips

comments.text:
First, I will say I am a Fan of the Hank Green. I think it was 
inappropriate that the media presented you as some crazy nut, with no 
intelligence. You were a great candidate and asked fantastic questions.

In response to your: "Holy Shit, I Interviewed the President:" link, I have 
a few things to say:

1)Glozell Green is not a great candidate...I feel like you are almost 
obligated to defend her (you preach no "judging" and are a fellow youtuber 
etc.). She does not strike me, in the least, as intelligent enough for 
legitimate input for the president. Just no, I am sorry, just no.
Bethany Mota represents, to a degree, this generation and can have 
legitimate input. Glozell Green is 52 and does absolutely degrading things 
for entertainment. She is not worth the president's time.

1a) The fact that you don't find anything wrong with her saying "dick" in a 
conversation with the president is disturbing to me. You claim this as 
being "honest", yet its actually just rude and disrespectful. Being honest 
doesn't mean losing basic manners, especially when you're in the presence 
of the President of the United States!
Bethany Mota was being honest, I respect that, but Glozell Green was 
showing her ignorance and poor manners.

2)What do you consider proper distribution of the news?
Politics is boring. Period. In my opinion, Comedy Central "news" shows are 
pretty much mocking everything that pops into their face. Its pure 
entertainment, not news.

Interviewing Youtubers was chosen for entertainment. People of today expect 
a plethora of entertainment at every turn. Which some would argue is 
exactly what is hurting the political involvement with this new generation. 
You can't make Politics entertaining; you have to actually enjoy it 
personally. People used to be involved because they had too; not because it 
entertained them.
Is this argument a legitimate concern, today?﻿

Beautiful video in all senses - the script, the thoughts within, and the 
land and sea shots. I am so sorry you have had to produce such a lovely 
video as a reaction to such hateful language, but as you (and many of us) 
know invention and art often comes from starting points of cruelty and 
horror and meanness. I am glad that you have the heart to make beauty and 
share good thoughts in the face of it all. ﻿

comments.text:
Hank, you realize when the media bashes you and your other youtube 
interviewers it is because no one wants to focus on how messy things are 
politically (in the real world) . Its much easier to focus on the guy 
interviewing the president ( you =)), make a judgement and have a feeling 
of some self worth for 2 secants than it is to stand up and say and or type 
something productive about the issues you and Obama talked about. Taking 
verbal jabs are a distraction for those who do not want to confront the 
real problems. Personally I'm sad that in this country we use gossip as a 
form of defending our own personal stupidities. You know your worth and you 
know how to have fun, and how to be a loving human. Thats more than most.﻿
comments.author: nicole martinez

comments.text:
What you said about monoculture sounds a lot like dystopian worlds such as 
that in the Hunger Games. It kind of reminds me how popular dystopian 
stories are these days, and makes me wonder if their popularity has 
anything to do with the threat of monoculture or closed-mindedness in the 
present day. Certainly there are no shortages of bigots over various 
issues, and terrorism is another extreme example of today's problems. Some 
cultures are more open and positive than others, but in either case there 
are always those who feel wronged in their culture. But I like to think 
we're moving forward, even if it doesn't feel like it to all groups in the 
world.﻿

comments.author: Jess Wagstrom

comments.text:
Hank, I am absolutely inspired by your reaction to harassment and cruelty. 
That you can take people being angry at you and turn it into a moment to 
heal others and yourself, to be thoughtful and sincere, is something that I 
admire intensely. I also greatly admire the strength that it takes to admit 
one's own imperfections, and as often as I see celebrities denying them, I 
am grateful to see you beginning to do so. (I am also grateful that it 
isn't just you, but that it is becoming an overwhelming trend.)
Thank you so much for bringing us a way to think critically about our own 
viewpoints as well as others, and thank you for helping us to celebrate 
diversity, as you do in this video.﻿
comments.author: Rhyanna Bredlau
